sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a vaporization reaction
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the vaporization of 100 g of water at 100°C given that the enthalpy of vaporization of water is 40.7 kJ/mol.
message_2:
First, we need to convert the mass of water (100 g) into moles. The molar mass of water (H₂O) is 18.015 g/mol.

moles of water = mass / molar mass
moles of water = 100 g / 18.015 g/mol
moles of water ≈ 5.55 mol

Now, we can use the enthalpy of vaporization (ΔHvap) to calculate the standard enthalpy change for the vaporization of 100 g of water.

ΔH = moles × ΔHvap
ΔH = 5.55 mol × 40.7 kJ/mol
ΔH ≈ 225.89 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the vaporization of 100 g of water at 100°C is approximately 225.89 kJ.
